title: 110_s1366
content: Consolidation of life insurance companies with other companies is permitted. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes changes to definitions and subsections related to includible corporations and special rules for insurance companies. Amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes changes to various sections such as 1504(b)(2), 1504(b)(4), and 1504(c), with amendments to sections 805(a)(4)(E), 818(e)(1), 832(b)(5)(D)(ii)(II), and 864(e)(5)(A) as well. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is being amended to change various sections, including 1504(b)(2) and 1504(b)(4). Amendments are also made to sections 805(a)(4)(E), 818(e)(1), 832(b)(5)(D)(ii)(II), and 864(e)(5)(A). The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years starting after December 31, 2006. SEC. 2. PHASE-IN OF APPLICATION OF CERTAIN LOSSES AGAINST INCOME OF INSURANCE COMPANIES. Phase-in provision for taxable years after December 31, 2006, allows for the utilization of consolidated net operating losses of affiliated groups with domestic insurance companies subject to tax under section 801 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Losses not absorbed in carryback periods can be used to offset taxable income. The consolidated taxable income of affiliated groups with domestic insurance companies subject to tax under section 801 of the Internal Revenue Code can be offset by net operating losses. Unused losses can be carried over to future years, with limitations based on the applicable percentage. The applicable percentage for net operating losses carried over to future years is as follows: 40% for 2007, 50% for 2008, 60% for 2009, 70% for 2010, 80% for 2011, and 90% for 2012. Any increase in losses cannot be carried back before January 1, 2007, and no affiliated group can terminate. No affiliated group can terminate solely due to this section or related amendments. Adjustments to subsidiary stock basis upon consolidation reflect preconsolidation financial activities. Automatic waiver from the 5-year waiting period for reconsolidation is provided. The 5-year waiting period for reconsolidation under section 1504(a)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 can be waived for a corporation previously includible but later deemed nonincludible due to becoming a subsidiary of a nonincludible corporation. The Secretary may impose conditions.
